abstract.p: Michael Chang defeats No 7-seeded Patrick Rafter in second-round match in Hamlet Cup; other Hamlet Cup scores (S)

block.p: Michael Chang helped out in a Long Island soup kitchen this week and yesterday he interrupted his second-round match in the Hamlet Cup to assist a ball girl overcome by heat.
His heroics did not stop there.
Michael Chang helped out in a Long Island soup kitchen this week and yesterday he interrupted his second-round match in the Hamlet Cup to assist a ball girl overcome by heat.
His heroics did not stop there.

Just five hours after defeating Byron Black, 7-5, 1-6, 6-4, in a match that had been rained out the previous night, Chang was back on the stadium court last night in Commack, N.Y., where he defeated the No. 7-seeded Patrick Rafter, 6-4, 6-4.
Rafter, a heavy crowd favorite, took the first game on four aces and then pounded Chang's serve to go up a break.
But the always patient Chang fought back from 0-3 to move into the quarterfinals of the Hamlet Cup for the sixth time since 1992.

In the daytime portion of his doubleheader, Chang was up a break and leading by 30-15 in the second game in the second set against Black when he suddenly dashed to the back of the court and caught 15-year-old Rebecca Shore of Smithtown, N.Y., in his arms as she was about to topple over.

After making sure Shore was safely off the court (she was dehydrated, her father said), Chang double-faulted that game away and lost the next three games en route to dropping the set. But he came back to win, setting up a quarterfinal match with Arnaud Clement today.
